Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Sapulvado JG et al; Environ Sci Technol 45: 8106-112 (2011)

StringWithMarkup.String: The log Koc of perfluorooctanoic acid was reported as 1.92-2.59 measured in three soils(1). According to a classification scheme(2), these log Koc values suggest that perfluorooctanoic acid is expected to have high to moderate mobility in soil. Based on a variety of conditions, pKa values of perfluorooctanoic acid  have been reported as -0.5 to 4.2(3), indicating that this compound will exist entirely in anion form and anions generally do not adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts(4). The log Koc and log Kd is 10 and 21 in sediment samples collected from Etobicoke Creek, Canada were reported as 0.88-1.85 and 0.16-1.44, respectively(5). The log Kd in 19 sediment samples collected from major rivers, lakes and canals in The Netherlands, May to Aug 2007 was 1.19-2.85(6). The log Koc and log Kd were reported as 2.6-4.2 and 1.3-2.8, respectively, in 32 sediment samples collected along the Haihe River, China; samples were collected April to May 2010(7). The average and median values for log Koc in 17 sediments were both 2.1(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: Perfluorooctanoic acid concentration in groundwater samples from a well close to a former fire-training burn pit (1950s to 1988) at Naval Air Station Fallon, NV was 6570 ug/L, the concentration was 460 ug/L in a sample from a well downstream of the former pit in the direction of the flow of groundwater(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected in the two other wells farther out from this former burn pit(1). At Tyndall Air Force Base, FL concentrations in groundwater were 116, 64, and 42 ug/L, moving away from the former fire training pit (1980-1992) in the direction of flow of the groundwater, and was not detected in a well in the opposite direction of the flow of groundwater(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in four of 19 well water samples at 149.2-6410 ng/L, samples were taken around Decatur, AL, from area farms that have a history of being treated with fluorochemical industry impacted biosolids(2). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected  at 0.34-3.7 ng/L in five groundwater samples collected Feb to March 2010 from Scarborough Bluffs, Canada on the shore of Lake Ontario(3). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in all 16 groundwater and spring water samples collected from the Tokyo, Japan metropolitan area between Sept and Nov 2006 at 0.47-60 ng/L(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in 53 samples collected Oct 2007 to Oct 2009 from wells in Tokyo, Japan at <0.25-1800 ng/L(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in 15 of 23 New Jersey public water systems sampled in 2006 at concentrations ranging from 0.005 to 0.39 ug/L(1). A concentration range of 33-120 ng/L was reported for perfluorooctanoic acid in drinking water plant effluent samples from six treatment utilities located in Colorado, Arizona, Nevada, Minnesota, Georgia, and California, sampled in 2008; detection limit 5.0 ng/L(2). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 2.3-84 ng/L in 14 drinking water plant samples collected in Osaka, Japan between July 2006 to March 2007(3). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 6.5-48 ng/L (raw water concentrations were 10-42 ng/L) in finished water from 5 drinking water purification plants from Osaka, Japan; samples were collected July 2007 to Feb 2008(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in 5 samples collected Oct 2007 to Oct 2009 from public sources in Tokyo, Japan at 4.7-12 ng/L(5). The concentration of perfluorooctanoic acid was monitored through a water treatment facility in Amsterdam, The Netherlands; intake concentration from Lek canal was 3.8-5.1 ng/L, finished water concentrations were 3.6-6.7 ng/L, concentrations at monitored steps ranged from 0.8 to 11 ng/L(6). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in four tap water samples from Amsterdam, The Netherlands at 3.2-4.3 ng/L(7). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 0.65-2.5 ng/L in drinking water samples collected in three homes that receive water from different water works in Oslo, Norway, samples were collected between Oct 2008 and Jan 2009(8). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in 27 of 56 tap water samples at <10-47 ng/L; samples were collected July 1 to Sept 4, 2008 from residence of Lake Mohne, Germany(9).

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Surface water samples taken from US streams in the Great Lakes basin tested positive for perfluorooctanoic acid in 93% of 44 samples taken 1994 to 2000 at concentrations of 0.00013 to 0.0700 ug/L(1). Water samples from the Tennessee River were collected in November 2000 starting 35 miles upstream from a fluorochemical manufacturing facility, effluent from the plant enters the river at mile marker 301(2). Between mile markers 337 and 297 concentrations of perfluorooctanoic acid were below quantification limit (<25 ng/L) and increased to 394 ng/L between miles 295 and 261(2). Concentration ranges in surface water samples collected in July 2004 from within New York State were as follows (ng/L): Lake Ontario 18-34; Niagara River 18-22; Lake Erie 13-27; Finger Lakes 11-20; Onondaga Lake 39-64; Oneida Lake 19 (mean); Erie Canal 25-59; Hudson River 22-173; Lake Champlain 10-46(3). Perfluorooctanoic acid was tested for in 100 samples from 80 locations in the Cape Fear Drainage Basin, NC in 2006; the highest total concentration reported was 287 ng/L; 26 (32%) of sample sites had concentrations above 40 ng/L(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid average concentrations in lake water samples (February - November 2006) collected near Albany, NY were 3.27-15.8 ng/L; detection limit = 0.25-0.75 ng/L(5). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in 25 of 32 surface water samples at 13.6-11,000 ng/L, samples were taken around Decatur, AL, from area ponds and streams near farms that have a history of being treated with fluorochemical industry impacted biosolids(6). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in water samples collected in 2003, 2006 and 2009 from Etobicoke Creek, (Toronto, Canada) at 16-58, 4.7-59 and 7.4-44 ng/L, respectively(7). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 2.2-7.9 ng/L in 29 surface water samples collected Feb to March 2010 from four locations along Highland Creek, which flows through the eastern part of Toronto, Canada and empties into Lake Ontario(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in 2 of 102 effluent samples from 52 treatment facilities located throughout Oregon at 390-500 ng/L; samples were collected the summer and fall of 2010(1). StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in sediment samples collected in 2003, 2006 and 2009 from Etobicoke Creek (Toronto, Canada) at <0.05-0.5, <0.05-0.2 and 0.1-0.2 ng/g wet weight, respectively(1). StringWithMarkup.String: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in fish samples collected in 2003, 2006 and 2009 from Etobicoke Creek (Toronto, Canada) at 0.1-0.4, <0.1-0.2 and <0.1 ng/g wet weight, and in fish liver samples at <0.1-2.5, 0.5-1.0 and <0.1-1.3 ng/g wet weight, respectively(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 0.8-2.3 ng/g in 9 of 44 fish (15 perch (Perca fluviatilis), 6 pike (Esox lucius), 5 eel (Anguilla anguilla), 8 cisco (genus Coregonus), 10 roach (Rutilus rutilus)) collected from Lake Mohne, Germany(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in pike from Norway and eelpout from Denmark at unreported concentrations(5). Blood samples from 18 cod (Gadus morhua), collected from the Gulf of Gdansk in Feb 2003, contained perfluorooctanoic acid at <50-700 pg/mL(6). Perfluorooctanoic acid concentrations of <50-370 ng/mL were reported in mullet (Mugil incillis) from the north coast of Columbia (Cartagena Bay), sampled in December, 2003(7).

StringWithMarkup.String: Perfluorooctanoic acid levels in herring gull eggs in 2007 from colonies spanning the Laurentian Great Lakes of North America were ranged from <0.10 to 2.6 ng/g wet weight(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 0.1 ng/g wet weight) in northern fulmar (Fulmarus glacialis) and thick-billed murre (Uria lomvia) eggs sampled 1971-2007 from Prince Leopold Island, Nunavut, Canada; in 2008, 2009 and 2011 perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in fulmar eggs at 0.17, 0.15 and 0.49 ng/g, respectively; in 2008, 2009, 2010 and 2011 it was detected in murre eggs at 0.23, 0.47, 0.05 and 0.05 ng/g, respectively; black guillemot (Cepphus grylle), black-legged kittiwake (Rissa tridactyla) and glaucous gull (Larus hyperboreus) eggs sampled in 2008 did not contain perfluorooctanoic acid(2). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in 2 of 81 bird livers collected from Japan (1997-1999) and Korea (1992-1994), the maximum concentration detected was 21 ng/g wet weight(3). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 60-100 pg/mL in blood samples from 16 eider duck (Somateria mollisima), collected from the Gulf of Gdansk in Feb 2003(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected (detection limit ng/g) in the muscle (0.60), kidney (1.2), adult liver (2.2), chick liver (0.76) or egg (0.99) of common guillemot (Uria aalge) samples from Stora Karlso Island in the Baltic Sea collected in 1989(5). Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 3 ng/g) in guillemot eggs from Storla Karlso, Sweden, on the Baltic Sea, over the years 1968-2003(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Concentrations in various Japanese animal livers sampled in February 2005 were 0.64-7.3, 3.5-6.1, 1.1-3.0, and >0.07-0.60 ng/g wet weight for cormorant, racoon dog, eagle, and large-bill crow, respectively(1). Perfluorohexanoic acid was not detected in fox (Vulpes vulpes) livers and chamois (Rupicapra rupicapra) livers; fox were collected from Germany and chamois from Austria(2). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at <=45 and <= 7.4 ug/kg in 529 liver and 506 muscle tissue samples, respectively from wild boar (Sus scrofa) collected Hesse, Germany between 2007 and 2009(3). The compound was detected at concentration ranges of 0.33-8.20 ug/L and 0.32-1.56 ug/L in serum from captive red panda and giant panda, respectively, in China(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in all grey seal (concentration not reported), but none of the minke whale or pilot whale samples taken from Sweden, Denmark, Iceland and the Faeroe Islands(5). Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected in livers of 78 and 84% of ringed seals (Phoca hispipa) collected 1982 to 2010 in West and East Greenland, respectively, concentrations peaked in 2006 and 2008 at average concentrations of 1.0-2.2 and 1.2-2.4 ng/g wet weight, respectively(6). In polar bear livers (Ursus maritimus) from East Greenland, perfluorooctanoic acid had annual average concentrations of 4.8-14.0 ng/g wet weight with the lowest average in 2011 and highest in 2006(6). Perfluorooctanoic acid mean concentration in liver tissue from East Greenland polar bears (Ursus maritimus) was reported as 236 ng/g wet weight(7). Perfluorooctanoic acid levels in the liver of approximately 7 yr old harbor seals (Phoca vitulina) from the German Bight over the years 1999-2008 were reported as (year, ng/g wet wt): 1988, 1.0; 1999, 1.4; 2000, 2.4; 2001, 3.3; 2002, 0.6; 2003, 0.8; 2005, 0.9; 2006, 0.8; 2007, 1.0; 2008, 0.3(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: Occupational exposure to perfluorooctanoic acid may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where perfluorooctanoic acid is produced or used. Exposure of ski wax technicians to perfluorooctanoic acid was reported; median blood level is 112 ng/mL compared to 2.5 ng/mL in the general Swedish population(1). The mean concentration range of perfluorooctanoic acid in plasma of New York State personnel responding to the World Trade Center disaster was shown to be 1.4-35.4 ng/mL, a 2-fold higher concentration than for the US population in general(2). Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to perfluorooctanoic acid via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing perfluorooctanoic acid(SRC).

StringWithMarkup.String: Serum concentrations of perfluorooctanoic acid in US samples collected in 1974 and 1989 were 2.3 and 5.6 ng/mL, respectively(1). Concentrations of perfluorooctanoic acid in 65 human serum samples purchased from various biological supply companies in the US ranged from <5 to 35.2 ng/mL(2). The concentration of perfluorooctanoic acid in the serum of 20 Atlanta, GA residents was 0.2-10.4 ng/mL, samples were collected July 2003(3). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 0.9-4751.5 ug/L in serum, collected Aug 2005 to Aug 2006, of 108 participants from Ohio and West Virginia that drink well water that contains 0.006-13.3 ug/L of perfluorooctanoic acid(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 1.1-8.9 ng/mL in the serum of 31 Boston, MA office workers in samples collected winter of 2009(5). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in the blood of all 12 California firefighters tested at 2-12 ng/g lipid; samples were collected in 2009(6). Perfluorooctanoic acid was frequently detected in 30 human hair samples; concentrations were not reported(7).

Reference: (1) Beesoon S et al; Environ Sci Technol 46: 12960-7 (2012)

StringWithMarkup.String: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 5.0-9.9 ng/mL (mean 7.6 ng/mL) in 40 pooled serum samples collected from 3802 Australian residents collected Nov 2002 to April 2003(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid concentration was 0.58 ng/mL (1977), increased to 5.2 ng/mL (1993), stabilized at 4.0 to 4.9 ng/mL (1994-2001), and then slowly decreased to 2.7 ng/mL by 2006 in 24 pooled serum samples from men, age 40 to 50 years, representing 1977 to 2006 in Norwegian residents(2). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in 66 human blood samples collected from 11 counties in Sweden during the period of 1997 to 2000, concentrations were 0.5-12.4 ng/mL(3).  Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 0.092-39.4 ng/mL in 420 human blood samples collected from volunteer residents from Halle and Munster, Germany; samples were collected 1982 to 2009(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 2.0-96.6, 0.7-99.7 and 1.1-77.5 ug/L in blood plasma samples of 170 children, 317 women and 204 men from the German population; samples were collected Sept to Nov 2006(5). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in blood serum samples collected July 1 through Sept 4, 2008 at 2.1-170 ug/L; samples were collected from 105 anglers (99 men, 6 women) that consumed fish from Lake Mohne, Germany(6). From 2006 to 2008, 233 human blood samples were taken from donors from the capital cities of 12 provinces or districts of China, perfluorooctanoic acid was detected as follows - city (ng/mL): Harbin (0.720), Hohhot (0.759), Lanzhou (1.40), Taiyuan (0.258), Shijiazhuang (1.50), Qingdao (1.42), Ningbo (3.87), Changsha (0.251), Chengdu (1.00), Chongqing (1.88), Kumming (1.13) and Guizhou (1.22)(7). Human blood samples from volunteer donors from five Chinese cities (Shenyang, Beijing, Gulyang, Jintan, Nanjing) collected in 2004 had perfluorooctanoic acid concentrations of <0.05-2.19 ng/mL(8).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Other nodes explore 'organofluorine compounds'; 'other diverse fluorinated compounds'; 'PFAS and fluorinated compound collections' (including CompTox; NORMAN-SLE; NIST; OntoChem PFAS lists) and 'regulatory PFAS collections' (including Stockholm Convention/EU regulations for PFOS; PFOA; PFHxS; LC-PFCAs). Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: EPA TSCA Classification
Reference.Description:
EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.

Reference.Name: SID 403382537
Reference.Description: The PATENTSCOPE database from WIPO includes patent and chemical structure search (with a free account) that gives access to millions of patent documents. The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) is a specialized United Nations (UN) agency headquartered in Geneva (Switzerland). Our mission is to lead the development of a balanced and effective international Intellectual Property (IP) system that enables innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. We help governments, businesses and society realize the benefits of Intellectual Property and are notably a world reference source for IP information.
LinkOut is a service that allows one to link directly from NCBI databases to a wide range of information and services beyond NCBI systems.
